relationships.notes: Pilate interrogates Jesus about kingship, declares him innocent yet yields to pressure, and authorizes crucifixion while posting the 'King of the Jews' inscription, making him the Roman adjudicator of the passion.
The chief priests, elders, and council deliver Jesus to Pilate’s headquarters, forcing a negotiation between Jewish leadership and the Roman governor over charges and execution.
Pilate sends Jesus to Herod Antipas upon learning he is a Galilean, and the two rulers become friends that day, illustrating interlocking Roman client relationships.
Peter’s sermons recall Pilate as the governor who handed over God’s Servant, framing the crucifixion as a joint action of Roman and Jerusalem authorities.
Paul and later Pauline tradition cite Pilate as the official who consented to Jesus’s death and before whom Christ made the 'good confession,' anchoring apostolic preaching in Roman judicial history.

traits.office_and_authority: Roman governor of Judea with power to interrogate Jesus and authorize crucifixion.
traits.interaction_with_jesus: Questions Jesus about being 'king of the Jews' and is struck by his silence under accusation.
traits.responsibility_for_crucifixion: Reluctantly yields to crowd pressure, releases Barabbas, and hands Jesus over to be crucified.
traits.character_portrayal: Appears politically cautious and expedient, more concerned with crowd management than justice, yet not portrayed as personally hostile.

traits.office_and_authority: Roman governor to whom Jesus is delivered after the Jewish leaders' deliberations.
traits.interaction_with_jesus: Questions Jesus about royal claims, recognizes the trial as driven by envy, and receives a warning from his wife based on a troubling dream.
traits.responsibility_for_crucifixion: Symbolically washes his hands to disclaim responsibility, yet formally authorizes the scourging and crucifixion while releasing Barabbas.
traits.role_in_passion_narrative: Presented as hesitant and somewhat sympathetic to Jesus, shifting primary blame toward the Jewish leaders and crowd, and later cooperating in securing the tomb.

traits.office_and_authority: Named as governor of Judea under Tiberius and associated with prior acts of brutality against Galileans.
traits.interaction_with_jesus: Examines Jesus, declares him innocent, sends him to Herod Antipas, and repeatedly proposes release.
traits.responsibility_for_crucifixion: Ultimately capitulates to crowd and leadership demands, authorizing crucifixion despite multiple stated findings of no guilt.
traits.character_portrayal: Depicted as a ruler who recognizes Jesus’ innocence but fails to act justly, constrained by political pressures and the desire to appease accusers.

traits.office_and_authority: Roman governor who conducts an extended interrogation of Jesus within the praetorium.
traits.interaction_with_jesus: Engages in a theological-political dialogue about kingship and truth, repeatedly states he finds no basis for a charge, yet becomes fearful when challenged about loyalty to Caesar.
traits.responsibility_for_crucifixion: Authorizes crucifixion after Jewish leaders invoke Caesar, and orders the inscription 'King of the Jews' to be placed on the cross and remain unchanged.
traits.character_portrayal: Drawn as conflicted and somewhat intrigued by Jesus, yet ultimately portrayed as a compromised official whose fear and political calculation override his recognition of Jesus’ innocence.

traits.role_in_salvation_history: Recalled as one of the rulers who, together with Jewish leaders and Herod, acts against Jesus in fulfillment of Scripture.
traits.responsibility_for_crucifixion: Portrayed as the authority who consented to Jesus' execution at the request of Jerusalem's inhabitants.
traits.character_portrayal: Functions primarily as a historical and theological reference point, an example of human rulers opposing God's servant yet unwittingly serving the divine plan.

traits.role_in_christ_confession: Mentioned as the official before whom Christ Jesus made a 'good confession,' anchoring Jesus’ witness in a specific historical judicial setting.
traits.function_in_letter: Serves as a point of comparison and exhortation for Timothy to keep the commandment faithfully, just as Christ bore witness before Pilate.
traits.character_portrayal: Not characterized in detail; functions mainly as a named Roman judge situating Jesus’ testimony within Roman legal context.
